Here is my code:

if (randfloat()<mutate_add_node_prob) {
        //cout<<"mutate add node"<<endl;
        new_genome->mutate_add_node(pop->innovations,pop-
>cur_node_id,pop->cur_innov_num);
        mut_struct_baby=true;
}
else if (randfloat()<mutate_add_link_prob) {
        net_analogue=new_genome->genesis(generation);
        new_genome->mutate_add_link(pop->innovations,pop-
>cur_innov_num,newlink_tries);
        delete net_analogue;
        mut_struct_baby=true;
}

In other words, it checks one, and then checks the other.  So 
actually it means, if you didn't add a node, then you have a 5% 
chance of adding a link.  Note the 3% and 5% numbers are only from 
pole balancing and other values were used in other experiments.  

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Philip Tucker" <ptucker@g...> wrote:
> Hi Ken,
> 
> Before getting to my question, a belated congratulations on your 
PhD!
>  A much deserved honor, I'm sure.
> 
> I'm just getting around to making the changes for our 
implementation
> of NEAT to do mutations more like yours; i.e., at most one 
topological
> mutation can occur per individual per generation.  Here's my 
question:
> 
> > "In smaller populations, the probability of adding a new node 
was 
> > 0.03 and the probability of a new link mutation was 0.05. In the 
> > larger population, the probability of adding a new link was 0.3."
> 
> > As for the final question of whether you can add a link and a 
node 
> > at the same time, in my system you can't.  However, it would 
hardly 
> > make a difference.  What makes a difference is adding big globs 
of 
> > structure all at once vs. adding just one or on a rare occasion 
two 
> > pieces.
> 
> Given a population, we have 2 sets of mutated individuals.  3% get 
a
> new node, 5% get a new connection.  How do you handle the 
intersection
> if no individuals can have both?  I can see 2 ways of doing it.
> 
> 1) For those that would get 2 mutations, flip a coin and choose 
one. 
> This would mean that slightly fewer than 3% and 5% are actually
> getting the mutation.  
> 2) Ensure there is no intersection.  Take 8% of the population to 
be
> mutated, then to 5/8 of those add a connection and to 3/8 add a 
node.
>    This could get counterintuitive with larger mutation rates; 
e.g.,
> if we had a 60% rate for add node and 60% rate for add connection,
> we'd actally wind up with 50% for both.
> 
> It's a fine point, and won't matter much if we always use very 
small
> mutation rates.  But I'd like my imlementation to make sense even 
if
> we decide to have larger rates, and I want it to be as close to 
yours
> as possible for comparing results.
> 
> Thanks,
> Philip
